doc:div.p: The RabbitMQ Server implements a number of extensions of the AMQP specification, which we are documenting here. There are also some experimental features, not directly related to the specification, which we consider to be useful but require further testing.

doc:section.name: unroutable-message-exchange
doc:section.doc:heading: Unroutable Message Exchanges
doc:section.p:
It is sometimes desirable to let clients handle messages that an exchange was unable to route (i.e. either because there were no bound queues our no matching bindings). Typical examples of this are
detecting when clients accidentally or maliciously publish messages that cannot be routed
"or else" routing semantics where some messages are handled specially and the rest by a generic handler
RabbitMQ's Unroutable Message Exchange ("UME") feature addresses these use cases.

doc:subsection.doc:heading: Configuration
doc:subsection.p: When creating an exchange the name of a UME can be optionally supplied in the exchange.declare method's arguments table by specifying a key of 'ume' and a value of type 'S' (string) containing the name.
When a UME has been specified, in addition to the usual configure permissions on the declared exchange, the user needs to have read permissions on that exchange and write permissions on the UME.

In the above fragment of Java code we create a direct exchange 'my-direct' that is configured with a UME called 'my-ume'. The latter is declared as a fanout exchange. We bind one queue 'routed' to 'my-direct' with a binding key of 'key1', and a queue 'unrouted' to 'my-ume'.

doc:subsection.doc:heading: Operation
doc:subsection.p: Whenever an exchange with a configured UME cannot route a message to any queue (or the message was marked as immediate and it cannot be delivered to any consumer) then it publishes the message to the specified UME instead. If that UME does not exist then a warning is logged.

Here we first publish a message to 'my-direct' with a routing key of 'key1'. That message is routed to the 'routed' queue, in accordance with the standard AMQP behaviour. However, when publishing a message to 'my-direct' with a routing key of 'key2', rather than being discarded the message is routed via our configured UME to the 'unrouted' queue.

When a UME cannot route a message, it in turn publishes the message to its UME, if it has one configured. This process continues until either the message is successfully routed, the end of the chain of UMEs is reached, or a UME is encountered which has already attempted to route the message.

The semantics of the 'mandatory' and 'immediate' flags carries through to UMEs. So, for example, if a sender specified the 'mandatory' flag on publication of a message, and that message could not be routed by the original exchange, but was then routed to a queue via a UME, then no basic.return is issued.
Message properties are carried through when messages are routed via UMEs. For example, when a message that was marked as persistent is routed to some queue via a UME then it does get persisted.

The queues to which a messages is routed from an UME participate in AMQP's tx transactions, i.e. if an unroutable message was published inside a tx then it will only appear in the queues when that tx is committed.

doc:section.name: memsup
doc:section.doc:heading: Memory-based flow control
doc:section.p: In versions of the RabbitMQ server prior to version 1.5.x, it was possible for clients to attempt to store so many messages within the server that it outgrew the available memory. With the release of version 1.5.x, an experimental memory-pressure-detection feature has been added to the codebase, so that when the server notices available memory drop below 5% of the total memory available to the system, it throttles publishers with the channel.flow AMQP command.

The feature has been tested and found to work on various Linux distributions, and is therefore enabled on those platforms by default. Please report back to the RabbitMQ mailing list your experiences using the feature on your platform!

doc:subsection.doc:heading: Usage
doc:subsection.p: To enable the feature when running the RabbitMQ on other platforms, add
to your RABBITMQ_SERVER_START_ARGS environment variable or to the SERVER_START_ARGS definition in /etc/rabbitmq/rabbitmq.conf, as appropriate for your platform.
Similarly, to disable the feature add
The memory threshold at which the flow control is triggered can be adjusted by modifying the -os_mon system_memory_high_watermark 0.95 line in the rabbitmq-server / rabbitmq-server.bat script.
